form.definition: noun G or g is the seventh letter of the English alphabet.
noun G is the fifth note in the musical scale of C major.
noun A gable is the triangular part at the top of a wall between the two sloping sides of a roof. See the picture at house.
gable roof A gable roof is a ridged roof with the two sides forming a gable at each end.
noun A gadget is a small machine or device which you use to perform a specific job. This is a handy little gadget for slicing potatoes.
verb If you gag someone, you put something over their mouth to stop them talking or making a noise. The gangsters gagged the girl and tied her to a chair.
verb If you gag on something, you choke on it as if you're about to vomit. Fred gagged on the rice puddingit was cold and tasted awful. They stumbled out, gasping and gagging because of the fumes.
noun A gag is a piece of cloth or tape put over someone's mouth to stop them talking or making a noise.
noun A gag is also a joke. I've heard that gag before, it's as old as the hills.
noun A gaggle is a flock of geese.
noun Gaiety is what you feel when you are happy and having fun. The party was a scene of gaiety and laughter.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See gay.

form.definition: verb If you gain something, you obtain it or acquire it, usually as a result of your efforts. Siri gained first prize in the singing competition. I gained promotion to departmental manager. She has gained a reputation for being unreliable.
verb If you gain something, you increase in that respect. The truck rolled down the hill, gaining speed as it went. The plane began to gain height. I've been gaining weight lately.
verb If a watch gains, it runs increasingly ahead of the correct time. My watch has been gaining several minutes a day latelyit's completely useless.

noun A gain is a profit or benefit that you get from something. My gain on the deal was $8. You will be helping other people and you'll have the gain of making new friends. He claimed not to be motivated by personal gain.
noun A gain is an improvement or increase. My end-of-year report shows that my hard work has paid off as I've made strong gains in maths. There has been another gain in the price of gold.
gain on If you gain on someone, you gradually catch up with them. I was gaining on Rob in the last lap of the raceanother hundred metres and I might have caught him.
noun Your gait is the way you walk or run. Ever since the car crash Maria's gait has been awkward. Just look at that racehorse's smooth gait.
noun A gala is a special occasion or celebration. Is your daughter racing at the swimming gala tonight? The orchestra plays at the gala in the park each Australia Day.
noun A galah is an Australian bird with grey and pink feathers.
noun In informal language, a galah is also a foolish person. Bill, you idiot! Stop acting like a galah.
noun A galaxy is an enormous group of stars extending over millions of kilometres in space. The radio telescope picked up faint signals from a distant galaxy.
noun A gale is a storm with very strong winds. The gum tree in our garden toppled over in the gale. It's blowing a gale outside.
noun Your gall bladder is a small, bag-like organ attached to your liver. It is part of your digestive system.
A gallery is a building where works of art are displayed to the public. Have you seen the new exhibition at the National Art Gallery?
noun The gallery in a theatre is a projecting balcony high up near the roof. Seats in the gallery are usually cheaper than in the stalls and circle.
noun A gallon was a unit of volume for measuring liquids in the imperial system, which is no longer used in Australia. It is equal to about 4.5 litres in the metric system.
verb When a horse gallops, it runs at top speed. The mare galloped towards the fence.

verb If you gallop through something, you do it very quickly, often because you want to finish it as soon as possible. He galloped through his lunch in ten minutes. She galloped through her studies and finished in three years instead of four.
noun Gallstones are small hard balls that can form in your gall bladder and may have to be removed in an operation.
noun A gallup poll is a survey of public opinion. It is carried out by questioning a sample of people who are selected to be representative of the population as a whole.
adverb If you have food galore or friends galore, you have as much or as many as you could possibly wish for.
verb If you galvanise iron or steel, you coat it with zinc to protect it and stop it rusting.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this is galvanize.

form.definition: verb If you galvanise someone into doing something, you shock them into taking action. The fall in profits has galvanised us into reviewing our marketing strategy.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective galvanised We bought galvanised iron for our roof.

form.definition: verb If you gamble, you bet money on the result of something, such as the way the two coins fall in a game of two-up. I gamble a few dollars a week on the horses. Shall we go gambling at the casino tonight?

verb If you gamble on something happening, you make your plans in the expectation that it will happen, although you realise that it may not. If it does you will gain a lot, and if it doesn't you will lose. He gambled his career on Mauricio gaining control of the board. The gangsters gambled on the fact that most people wouldn't bother checking up on them. ... WORD FAMILYnoun gamble We took a gamble on it being a sunny day for the picnic, and it paid off.noun gambler The casino was crowded with gamblers. He's a natural gambler.noun gambling She disapproves of gambling in all its forms.

noun A game is something you play to amuse yourself or to pass the time. Most games are played against an opponent and have fixed rules for the players to follow. How about a game of cards? Ty loves playing video games. The kids played a game of hide-and-seek. It's all just a game to you, isn't it? I refuse to go along with his little games.
noun Game is the wild animals and birds that people hunt for sport and the meat that comes from them. The section on game in the cookbook shows how to prepare kangaroo and emu.
adjective If you are game for something or game to do something, you are prepared to do it, even though it may be a little risky. Let's go for a midnight swimare you game?

give the game away If someone gives the game away, they reveal a secret. If we tell George about the surprise party, he's sure to give the game away to Heidi. He said he didn't know anything about it, but his shifty manner gave the game away.
noun Gaming is a rather formal word for gambling.

noun A gang is a group of people who work together or spend a lot of time together. A gang of criminals raided the bank. He became involved with a street gang. Our whole gang was at the party. A gang of bricklayers could finish the job in a week.

gang up on In informal language, if you say a group of people gangs up on someone else, you mean that they combine forces against that person. They act together to be mean to that person. The bullies always gang up on the new girls in the class. I hate it when you side with the kids and they all gang up on me!
noun Gangrene occurs if the flesh of a part of your body dies and rots. Often this happens because the blood supply to it has been cut off. She had to have her big toe amputated when gangrene set in.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective gangrenous

form.definition: noun A gangster is a criminal who belongs to an organised gang.
noun A gaol is a prison, where criminals are kept in custody.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this word is jail.

form.definition: noun A gap is an empty space between objects. There's a gap under the door where the wind blows in. I wore a brace to reduce the gap between my front teeth. He squeezed through a gap in the hedge.

noun A gap is also something missing or a lack of something. My memories of those times are full of gaps. There are serious gaps in his knowledge. The shortage of adequate child-care is a serious gap in social provision.

noun A gap is also the difference between two things. There's a gap of three hours between Sydney and Hong Kong in winter. The widening gap in ideas between the brothers led to conflict. The gap between my income and expenses is alarming.
verb If you gape at someone or something, you stare at them in amazement or horror, usually with your mouth wide open. I couldn't help gaping at my sister's bald head.
verb If something gapes, it splits or becomes wide open. His trousers gaped at the seams.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective gaping The soldier had a gaping wound in his stomach.

form.definition: noun A garage is a special part of your house or block of units where you keep your car, or it is a large building in a city where many people park their cars. You can get into the house through the garage. I parked on the third storey of the garage.

noun A garage is also a place where you buy petrol and where mechanics can fix your car if it breaks down. Another expression for this is service station. Syed has a part-time job at the local garage.
noun Garbage is domestic rubbish. The garbage is collected twice a week.
noun In informal language, if you say that someone is talking garbage, you mean that what they're saying doesn't make sense or isn't true. What utter garbage! Of course you're my best friend.
noun Your garden is the area of land around your house, where you can grow flowers, trees and shrubs. Go out into the garden and cut some herbs for the salad.
noun A public area with lawns and flowerbeds, where you can relax and enjoy yourself, is called a garden or gardens. Let's go for a picnic in the Botanical Gardens.

verb When you garden, you work in your garden, doing things such as mowing the lawn, removing weeds and looking after the plants. Many people in Australia enjoy doing this as a hobby. I spent the afternoon gardening.
Gardens Gardens is sometimes used as the second part of the name of a street. In writing this is often abbreviated to Gdns. I live at 105 Philbeach Gardens.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See gardener.noun gardening My hobbies include cooking and gardening.adjective gardening She loves reading gardening books. I bought a new pair of gardening gloves.

form.definition: noun A gardener is a person who looks after a garden, often for a wage. I'm a keen gardener. He works for the council as a gardener. I have a gardener come in once a week to look after the flowerbeds.
verb When you gargle, you move liquid around inside your mouth and at the back of your throat without swallowing it. You should gargle with salt water to kill the germs.

adjective If something is garish, it is a very bright and often unusual colour or combination of colours. It is not in good taste. They painted the outside of the house a garish green. The kids love those cheap ice blocks in garish colours. She wore a suit with garish stripes.
noun Garlic is a spice with a strong smell. It is used in cooking to add flavour.
noun A garment is a piece of clothing, such as a pair of trousers or a blouse.
verb If you garnish food, you decorate it so that it looks attractive. Garnish the duck with orange slices and olives.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun garnish Serve with a garnish of parsley.

form.definition: noun A garret is a very small room high under the roof of a house.
form.note: ... A SIMILAR WORDis attic.

form.definition: noun A gas is any substance like air which is neither solid nor liquid and which takes up the shape of the container that it is in. b noun Some kinds of gas are used as fuel, especially coal gas and natural gas. Our stove, heater and hot water service all use gas.
noun Gas is also an informal word for petrol. We're nearly out of gas.

verb If someone is gassed, they breathe poisonous gas until they get sick or die. His grandparents were gassed in a concentration camp. Seven workers were gassed by the fumes and taken to hospital. My mother tried to gas herself, but she was found in time.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective gaseous ...a gaseous element.adjective gassy I don't like mineral water that's too gassy.

form.definition: noun A gash is a long deep cut. Sam has a nasty gash on his leg. He made a gash in the tree trunk with his penknife.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb gash

form.definition: noun A gasket is a fitting made of metal or rubber which is used to seal a joint so that no gas or liquid can escape.

verb When you gasp, you draw your breath in suddenly because you are shocked or surprised. Milly gasped when she opened the envelope and saw her exam results. The audience gasped at the performance of the acrobats.

verb When you gasp, you struggle to breathe. You fight for breath, with your mouth open. She came out of the surf gasping for air. After the first few kilometres I was gasping, and felt I couldn't go on. He was brought out of the burning building choking and gasping.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun gasp

form.definition: adjective Gastric means relating to the stomach. ...a gastric ulcer. ...a gastric virus.

noun A gate is a frame which swings on hinges to open and shut like a door. It is used to control access into or out of an enclosed space in the open air or along a path. See the picture at house. Be sure and lock the back gate onto the lane when you go out. The sheep had wandered off through the open gate. Mark was swinging on the garden gate.
noun The gate at a sporting event is the number of people who pay to go and see it. The Rugby League final had a record gate of 100 000.
verb If you gatecrash a party, you go to it or try to get in although you haven't been invited. When the gang gatecrashed our party, my uncle told them to leave.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun gatecrasher The police asked the drunken gatecrashers to leave the dance.

form.definition: verb When people or things gather, they come together in a group. A large crowd gathered outside the court to wait for the verdict. Look at all the dust that's gathered under the bed.

verb If you gather objects, you collect them together. The speaker gathered his papers together and left the room. I love gathering berries from the bushes. I went to the library to gather information for my essay.
verb In sewing, if you gather cloth, you sew a thread through it and then pull the thread tight so that the cloth forms loose folds. The dress is gathered at the waist.

verb If you gather that something is the case, you draw a conclusion. Often you use this word to refer to what you've heard from other people rather than the person directly concerned. I gather from your comments that I'm not welcome here. I gather your brother isn't well. She's not a very popular manager, I gather.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun gathering The large gathering was silent as the news was announced.

dictionary.entry: gaudy`g@:di:gaudiergaudiest adjective If something is gaudy, it has very bold and bright colours and a striking design. She chose a gaudy outfit for the party. His paintings capture all the gaudy atmosphere of the fair. The gaudy cover certainly attracts attention to the book.

form.definition: noun A gauge is a device for measuring the amount of something. Dave gave me a handy pocket gauge for checking the air pressure in tyres. The petrol gauge showed the tank was nearly empty.
verb If you gauge something, you measure or estimate it. We need to do more market research to gauge the demand for such a product. At this stage, it's hard to gauge how much we'll need to spend.

verb If you gauge a person or situation, you assess them carefully and make a judgment about them. It was hard to gauge what he was thinking. I gauged it wasn't a good time to approach her. You have to gauge it just rightnot too much and not too little.
noun The gauge of something such as wire or sheet metal is its thickness. What gauge is the wire you're using for the job?
noun The gauge of a railway line is the distance between the two rails.
adjective If someone is gaunt, they are thin and their cheeks look hollow, often because they have been ill for a long time. I was horrified by the gaunt figures of the prisoners of war.
noun Gauze is a thin, light fabric with a very open weave. It is often used for bandages.
verb Gave is the past tense of give.
verb If you gawk at someone, you stare at them. Even though I knew it was rude, I couldn't stop gawking at the TV star.
adjective If someone is gawky, their movements are awkward and they are not confident of themselves. Daniel is just sixteen and going through the gawky stage.

adjective Someone who is gay is homosexual. They are sexually attracted to people of the same sex as themselves. When did you first realise you were gay? ...a gay bar. ...the gay and lesbian community. b noun A gay is a homosexual.
form.note: ... NOTEThis word is used particularly for male homosexuals. Female homosexuals are usually described as lesbian.2a adjective If you feel gay, you feel lively and cheerful. The spring weather made me feel much gayer. The band played a gay tune as the parade went by.

form.definition: adjective If something looks gay, it is bright and makes you feel happy. The girl's gay clothing made a splash of colour on the grey winter's day. The whole street was decked with gay streamers.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See gaiety.adverb See gaily.

form.definition: verb If you gaze at someone or something, you look at them steadily and for a long time. As I gazed at the picture of my aunt, I realised how much alike we looked. He sat gazing into the fire. She gazed at him in adoration.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun gaze Her gaze remained fixed on the ground. An amazing sight met our gaze.

form.definition: verb If you gazump someone, you break an agreement to sell them your house or unit. You sell it to someone else for a higher price.

dictionary.entry: Gdns abbreviation for Gardens. It is usually used when you write an address.

form.definition: abbreviation for Gross Domestic Product. This is the total value of goods and services produced within a country in a year.

noun A gear in a machine or vehicle is a device that transmits movement between the different parts and allows you to vary the speed and direction of movement. Try not to crash the gears as you drive. The gear seems to be slipping. I put the car into gear, released the clutch and edged forward.

noun A gear in a vehicle is also a specific setting of the mechanism for transmitting energy to the wheels. A manual car has four or five forward gears and one reverse gear. Trucks change down into low gear before they descend a steep hill.
noun Gear is a general word for the equipment you need for a certain purpose or job. I store my skiing gear in the attic. I haven't got the right gear to change the washers on the taps.

noun In informal language, your gear is your clothes. Do I have time to change my gear before we go out for dinner? I hate the way the kids leave their dirty gear all over the floor. She certainly gets herself up in some strange gear.
noun Gel is a thick transparent paste that some people put in their hair to keep it in place.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb gel (gels, gelled, gelling) I gelled my hair to give it more body.

form.definition: noun Gelatine is a substance that you use in cooking to make jelly. It is also used in industry to make things such as glue and film.
noun A gem is a precious stone which is cut and polished for use in jewellery. The brooch contains some magnificent gems. Most diamonds are not of sufficient quality to become gems.

noun A gem is also something that's very attractive or useful, or which is valued for some other reason. The village where we stayed is a undiscovered gem. This recipe book is a real gemI've relied on it for years. Thanks for helping me outyou're a gem!
noun Your gender is your sexmale or female. Employers are not allowed to discriminate on the basis of gender.

noun In the grammar of some languages, certain words and forms belong to a specific genderfor example, masculine and feminine in French; masculine, feminine and neuter in German; common and neuter in Dutch.
noun Your genes are the microscopic parts in all the cells of your body which transmit characteristics from one generation to the next.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective genetic

form.definition: adjective If something is general, it is not precise or specific. She spoke of the problems only in general terms. His description was so general that it could apply to anyone.

adjective You use general to refer to something in an overall way, without giving details, or to indicate that you are talking about the thing as a whole rather than a particular type of it. I've been feeling a general apathy lately. The whole house needs a general clean. There's one course in general Japanese and one in Japanese for business.

adjective If something is general, it is widespread or concerns a large number of people. There is general anger at this policy. The council carries out projects for the general good of the community. How general is this problem? Have any others of you run into it?
noun In the Australian army, a general is an officer of the highest rank.
general election A general election is held when the state or federal parliament is dissolved and elections are held in all seats to vote for new members. Compare this with by-election.
in general In general refers to a situation as a whole. I'm talking about society in general, not just the middle class. In general he's very kind, but everyone can have a bad day.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun generality (generalities) She spoke only in generalities.adverb generally This is what generally happens. I just feel generally miserable.verb generalise (<or> generalize) It's unwise to generalise from such a small number of cases.

form.definition: verb If something generates something, it creates or causes it. This power plant generates electricity for the whole region. His remarks have generated a lot of controversy. The fair generated a large amount of money for the school.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun generator In case of power failure, we can switch to the emergency generator.

form.definition: noun A generation is all the people who are at the same level of descent in a family tree. Your cousins twice removed are two generations older or younger than you. The feud was carried on into the next generation.

noun A generation is all the people in a society who are born at about the same time. Our parents belong to a different generationwe can't expect them to share our ideas about everything. The first post-war generation is now approaching retirement age.

noun A generation is a period of about thirty years, the length of time from when someone is born to when they are in the middle of having their own family. A whole generation has passed since we were at school together.

adjective If something is generic, it has the characteristics of a class or type of things rather than individual ones of its own. Her novels are populated by generic heroes and villains. He used 'cool' as a generic term of approval.

adjective Generic products are marketed under the name of the store in which they're sold rather than the company which makes them. Generic brands are usually cheaper because advertising costs are kept to a minimum.
adjective Generic drugs are non-proprietary varieties, listed in the Australian Pharmacopoeia.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb generically Houses and units are known generically as dwellings.

form.definition: adjective If you are generous, you are prepared to give a lot to people or do a lot to help them. He was very generous to his children. She is always generous with her time. They made a generous donation. That's a very generous offer. It was generous of her to forgive him.

adjective If something is generous, it is large. He served me a generous helping of chocolate cake. The sizes are generous, so a 14 should be OK. He covered the canvas with generous brush strokes. ... WORD FAMILYnoun generosity I should like to thank our sponsors for their generosity in supporting us.adverb generously She generously gave me a lift, though it was rather out of her way.
noun The genesis of something is its beginning or how it came about. The genesis of the present conflict was the contested election.
noun Genetics is the study of heredity. It examines how characteristics are passed on from one generation to the next.
adjective If someone is genial, they are friendly and pleasant. He was in a genial mood at the party, but he can be a pig at home.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb genially He greeted us genially and showed us into the dining room.

form.definition: noun Your genitals are the parts of your body that are used in sexual intercourse.
form.note: ... SEE THE PICTUREat body.

form.definition: noun A genius is someone who is extremely clever and talented, often in a particular field. Mozart was a musical genius. You're a genius! However did you do it? It didn't take a genius to work out that the news was bad.

noun Genius is very great talent or skill, often in a particular field. The roots of mathematical genius are unclear. She has a real genius for designing clothes. He has yet to find a way to profit from his genius.
noun Genocide is the murder of a whole community or race of people. Hitler planned the genocide of the Jewish people.

noun A genre is a type of literary work that shares certain characteristics. You have to answer at least one question on each of the genres of poetry, prose and drama. She's an excellent writer of thrillers, but less sure when she steps outside the genre.
noun A gentile is someone who is not Jewish. Hiram's sister married a gentile.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective gentile They have as little as possible to do with gentile society.

dictionary.entry:
gentle`dZEntlgentlergentlest 1 adjective If you are gentle, you treat people kindly and patiently. Under gentle questioning she revealed the whole story. I'm normally a gentle person, but he made me really angry. The teacher
adjective If you are gentle, you handle things carefully and delicately. Be gentle with the puppiesthey're still only tiny. I gave it a gentle shove to get it moving. I felt a gentle tap on my shoulder.
adjective If something is gentle, it is not extreme or harsh. There was a gentle slope up to the house. A gentle breeze was blowing. He gave me a gentle hint about the time. Use a gentle detergent on these delicate fabrics.
... WORD FAMILYnoun gentleness adverb gently

form.definition: noun Gentleman is a polite way of referring to a man. I'm serving this gentleman at the moment. Would the young gentleman at the back like to comment on that? Well, gentlemen, shall we move to a vote?
adjective If something is genuine, it is real and not fake. The expert confirmed the painting as a genuine Van Gogh. The ring is set with genuine diamonds. His disappointment was genuine.
adjective If someone is genuine, they are open and natural in their behaviour. They're not acting insincerely to try to impress people. June's a nice, genuine sort of girl.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb genuinely noun genuineness

form.definition: noun Geography is the study of the planet we live on, including its land masses and oceans, and the climate and people in different regions.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun geographer adjective geographical

form.definition: noun Geology is the study of the rocks which form the earth and how these have changed and are still changing.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective geological noun geologist

form.definition: noun Geometry is the branch of mathematics concerned with lines, angles and shapes.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective geometrical

form.definition: adjective If someone is geriatric, they are old and often unable to care for themselves. The nurses here are specially trained to look after geriatric patients.
adjective If something is geriatric, it is very old and no longer functions very well. This geriatric photocopier breaks down at least once a week.
adjective Geriatric also means relating to geriatrics. He was moved to the geriatric ward.
noun Geriatrics is the branch of medicine concerned with the health of old people.
noun A germ is a very small living organism that can cause disease, such as a bacterium or virus. Scrub your hands with soap to get rid of the germs. Don't come breathing your filthy germs over me!
noun A germ is also the very beginning of something. The germ of an idea started to take shape in my mind. The germs of this conflict go back a decade or more.
noun German is the language of Germany, Austria and parts of Switzerland.
adjective If something or someone comes from Germany, you describe them as German.

German measles German measles is an infectious disease which causes a rash and a fever for a short time. It is dangerous for women to catch it in the early months of pregnancy because it can cause deformities in the foetus.
form.note: ... NOTEThe medical name for this is rubella.

form.definition: noun A gerrymander is an unfair division of the population into voting districts that gives an advantage to one of the political parties when an election is held.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb gerrymander

form.definition: verb If you gesticulate, you make a lot of gestures, because you are excited or because you are trying to convey a meaning without words. He gesticulated wildly as he told the story. I could see her gesticulating on the other side of the glass.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun gesticulation

form.definition: noun If you make a gesture, you move part of your body to express an emotion or meaning, or to emphasise what you are saying. He made a gesture of welcome as we arrived. She makes a lot of gestures while speaking. He silenced them with a gesture. Gestures can mean different things in different cultures.

noun If you make a gesture towards someone, you do something to show them how you feel. We invited our new neighbours to dinner as a gesture of friendship. The present's not much, but it's a gesture. She condemned the consultation process as an empty gesture.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb gesture He gestured for the bill.

form.definition: verb If something gets a certain way, it becomes like that. She got very fat in Italy. He often gets angry for no reason. I'm sure I'm getting taller. It's getting cold in here. The days are getting shorter.

verb If something gets somewhere, it arrives there. When will they get here? How are you getting home? Did you get to India on your travels? How did this get here? The bird got out of the cage and flew off.

verb If you get something, you obtain or acquire it. We got dinner from the take-away. You should get advice from an expert. It wasn't easy to get a mortgage. Could you get me a loaf, please? You need to get a haircut.
verb If you get something, you fetch it. Just let me get my glasses. I went to get some ice from the kitchen. I have to get the kids at three. Shall I come and get you in the car?

get If you get something in a certain condition or place, you cause it to be like that. I got my hands dirty. You've got glue all over the table. I couldn't get all the pieces back. Now you've got him angry. I hope I haven't got you out of bed?

verb If you get something done, or if you get somebody to do something, you cause it to be done. I got a new carpet laid. We finally got her to admit her mistake. Could I get you to move along a bit? He's the sort of person who gets things done.
verb If you get some form of transport, you take it or catch it. Get a 431 or 432 bus. I usually get the ferry to work. He gets the 7.33 every day. If we hurry we should get the 9.42.
verb If you get a meal, you prepare it. I'll start getting dinner in a minute.
verb If you get someone at a particular time or place, you manage to contact them. You can get me on this number tomorrow. The best time to get me is between nine and ten.
verb In informal language, if you say you get something, you mean you understand it. I didn't get the joke. I just don't get ithow could she be so stupid? There's just one point I don't get.

get ahead If you get ahead, you make progress or are successful in something you are trying to do. Presentation skills are important if you want to get ahead in your career. At first the course was really difficult, but after a few weeks I began to feel I was getting ahead.
get at If you get at someone, you nag or tease them. She's always getting at me about something.
get away with If you get away with something, you do not get punished for something wrong that you've done, often because no-one is aware of it. Rasha got away with cheating in the exam.
get by If you get by, you manage to cope with a situation. They are hoping to get by on $200 a week for food and accommodation. My Japanese isn't good, but I get by.
get down If something gets you down, it makes you depressed. The wet weather is really getting me down.
get off You can say someone gets off if they manage to avoid being punished for breaking a law. The prisoner got off because the police had insufficient evidence.
get on (a) If you get on, you make progress with something. Stop talking and get on with your work. At last I began to feel I was really getting on in my studies.
(b) When you get on, you become old. My father's getting on, you knowhe's over seventy now. As you get on, your joints become less supple.

(c) If you get on with someone, you have a friendly relationship with them. Leif and Nadia are getting on well these days. I've never really got on with her. You don't have to be great friends with your colleagues, but you do have to get on with them.
get over If you get over an illness or disappointment, you recover from it. I still haven't got over the flu. Anthea seems to be getting over her broken engagement at last.

adjective You can say something is ghastly if you dislike it or find it very unpleasant. He wore a ghastly green suit. They served up some sort of ghastly stew. What ghastly weather! He's a ghastly person to work with. We had a ghastly time on our holidays.
noun A gherkin is a type of small cucumber which has been kept for a long time in salt water and vinegar.

noun A ghetto is a part of a city where people of one ethnic group live separately from the rest of the community. Ghettos often have serious social problems. He's a tough kid who grew up in a New York ghetto. The suburb was becoming a ghetto controlled by drug lords.
noun A ghost is the spirit of a dead person which appears to and haunts living people. A similar word is apparition. Do you believe in ghosts? He was visited by the ghost of his father.
noun A ghost of something is a very faint indication of it. He hasn't a ghost of a chance. A ghost of a smile played about her lips. In this image you can see the ghost of the original painting.

give up the ghost In informal language, if you say something gives up the ghost, you mean that it breaks down so badly that it's not worth repairing it. We bought a new washing machine after our old one gave up the ghost.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective ghostly I could see a ghostly form. There was a ghostly echo in the tunnel.

form.definition: noun In fairytales and myths, a giant is someone who is very large and strong, several times the size of a normal person.
noun A giant is a person or thing who is much larger than normal. A genetic abnormality caused him to grow to be a giant. That cabbage looks as if it's going to be a giant.
noun A giant is also someone who is very important, famous or talented. He's one of the giants of the twentieth century.

adjective If something is giant, it is very large. The honeymoon suite has a giant four-poster bed. We had a giant argument yesterday. There has been a giant improvement in their performance since last year.
verb If you gibber, you talk very quickly in a confused way, often because you are very shocked or frightened. She was gibbering so much that I couldn't understand what she was saying.
noun Gibberish is speech or writing that doesn't make sense. The computer has turned the text into gibberish.

adjective When you feel giddy, you feel as though your head is spinning around and you will lose your balance. If you feel giddy, move away from the edge. I was giddy with excitement. ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is dizzy. ... WORD FAMILYnoun giddily noun giddiness
noun Gift is a rather formal word for a present. My daughter received some lovely gifts for her birthday. Visit our stand at the exhibition and take home valuable gifts and prizes!
noun If you have a gift for something, you have natural talent and are very good at it. Tomoko has a real gift for flower arranging.

noun In informal language, if you say something is a gift, you mean it is cheap, or easier to do than expected. The strawberries are a gift at that price. The last question in the exam was a gift as we'd just studied the topic in class.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective gift Our gift department is on your left. I bought a roll of gift wrapping.adjective gifted She is a gifted musician. He is artistically gifted.

form.definition: adjective If something is gigantic, it is very large. I felt lost in the gigantic city. In my dream I was being chased by a gigantic rabbit. They face gigantic problems in rescuing the company.
verb If someone giggles, they give a high-pitched laugh. The two girls couldn't stop giggling. Mario giggled nervously at our compliments.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun giggle Lorna let out a giggle. He's got a very irritating giggle.

form.definition: verb If you gild something, you cover it with thin sheets of gold or with gold paint. ...a mirror with a gilded frame.
adjective If something is gilt, it is gold-coloured. She carried the glasses in on a gilt tray. I chose a pair of glasses with gilt rims.
noun A gimmick is something done to attract attention, and not because it is useful or worthwhile. The agency has thought up a clever gimmick for promoting our toothpaste.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective gimmicky

form.definition: noun Ginger is a spice which comes from the part of the plant's stem that is under the ground. It is used in cooking and herbal medicine.
adjective If something is ginger, it is a light reddish-brown colour. ...a ginger cat. ...ginger hair.
adverb If you do something gingerly, you do it with very careful and cautious movements. I gingerly prodded the animal to see if it was dead. He edged his way gingerly back along the balcony.
adjective A gingerly movement is careful and cautious. I gave it a gingerly prod.
noun Gingham is a cotton fabric with a checked pattern, usually white and one other colour.

noun A gipsy is a member of a race of people who originally came from India and now live mainly in Europe. Traditionally, gipsies do not have permanent homes but move from place to place. They often train and sell horses, and make and sell craft items.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this word is gypsy.

form.definition: noun A girl is a female child.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun girlhood She spent her girlhood in the bush.adjective girlish She still has a slim, girlish figure. She gave a girlish laugh.

form.definition: noun A girlfriend of a man or boy is a girl or woman with whom he is having a sexual or romantic relationship.
noun The girth of something is its measurement around the middle. These ancient trees can grow to a girth of over three metres. His vast girth was contained in a pair of corduroy trousers.

noun The gist of something such as a report or news item is a summary or the most important part of it. Navin told me the gist of his adventures overseas. Don't tell me the whole story, just give me the gist. I couldn't follow every word, but I got the gist of what they were saying.

verb If you give something to someone, you offer it to them freely. What are you giving her for Christmas? Inge gave me her book to read. I give to charity regularly. We should give them our support. Children need to be given love.
verb If you give someone money in return for something, you pay them. June gave the kids $3 each to wash the car. I'll give you $50 for that old table. I'd give a lot to have another chance.
verb If something gives you a feeling, it causes you to experience it. Your visit has given me a lot of pleasure. She gave the impression of being quite content.
verb If you give someone a right, opportunity or responsibility, you allow or grant it to them. He pleaded to be given another chance. I've been given the job of organising the meeting.
verb If you give a party, you organise it and act as the host. He gave a party to celebrate his return.
verb If you give someone information, you tell it to them. I haven't given Takashi the phone message yet. This brochure gives all the bus times. No-one could give me an answer to my question.

give away (a) If you give something away, you give it to someone else and no longer have it yourself. I usually give away my old clothes to the St Vincent de Paul Society. He inherited a fortune, but gave it all away in a year. At that price, I'm practically giving it away!
(b) If you give something away, you reveal it, often when it is supposed to be secret. She didn't give much away in the interview. He didn't say he was Australian, but his accent gave him away.
give in If you give in, you admit that you are beaten or wrong about something. I give in, you win! They vowed that they would never give in to tyranny.
If something gives off a gas or a smell, it causes it to be released from itself into the air. Carbon dioxide is given off during the reaction. The bouquet gave off a wonderful scent.
give out (a) If you give things out, you distribute them. Could you give out these lecture notes for me, please.
(b) If you give out information, you let it be known. They gave out details of the meeting to the press. He gave it out that he wasn't happy with the way things were going.
give up (a) If you give something up, you stop doing it. I gave up smoking five years ago. He gave up his job to travel round the world.

(b) If you give up, you despair, or you abandon an attempt because you think you will never be successful. Don't give up nowthere's only another two laps to go. I'd given up hope of ever seeing him again. You'd be mad to give up on your big chance.
(c) If you are trying to guess the answer to a question and you can't get it right, you say that you give up. Tomatoes? Capsicums? Onions? No, I give up, what is it?
(d) If you give yourself up to the police or other people in authority, you surrender yourself to them. The escaped prisoner gave himself up after a week.
give way (a) If you give way in traffic, you let another vehicle go ahead of you. That driver should have given way to meI entered the roundabout first.
(b) If something gives way, it falls apart under pressure. Suddenly the chair gave way beneath him. I pushed firmly until the seal gave way.
noun Your given name is the name that distinguishes you from other members of your family and other people with the same surname. No, Zhang is her surname and Muoi is her given name.
noun A glacier is a river of ice which moves very slowly down a mountain.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective glacial

form.definition: adjective If you are glad about something, you are pleased about it. I'm glad you're feeling better now. I enjoyed my travels, but I'm glad to be back in Australia. 'Thank you.' 'Not at all, I was glad to help.' He didn't seem very glad to see us.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb gladly 'Could you give me a hand?' 'Gladly.' I'll gladly pay half the cost.

form.definition: noun Glamour is an attractive charm that things have because they seem mysterious and remote from everyday experience. My sister loves the glamour of being a fashion model.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGof this is glamor. ... WORD FAMILYadjective glamorous She envied him his glamorous life. You're looking very glamorous today!

form.definition: verb If you glance at something, you look at it quickly. She was so afraid of missing the train that she glanced at her watch every few minutes. I've only had a chance to glance at today's papers.
verb If something glances off something else, it strikes it and then goes off in another direction. The bullet glanced off the side of the tree.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun glance I cast a glance in her direction. I've only given the report a glance so far.adjective glancing It was only a glancing blow.

form.definition: noun A gland is an organ in your body which makes and secretes a substance that helps to regulate the way your body functions. ...sweat glands. ...the thyroid gland.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective glandular

form.definition: verb If you glare at someone, you look at them steadily in a very angry way. I glared at the motorist who didn't stop for me to cross the road.
noun Glare is brilliant dazzling light, usually from the sun. I have to wear sunglasses to protect my eyes from the glare.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun glare He shot me an angry glare.

form.definition: adjective If something is glaring, it is so obvious that you can't help noticing it. How embarrassing! There's a glaring error in my report. The company is handicapped by a glaring lack of talent in the upper levels of management.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb glaringly It's glaringly obvious he's the wrong person for the job.

form.definition: noun Glass is a hard transparent substance used to make things like windows, bottles and jars. Glass breaks easily if it is dropped or hit. You should use tough glass for the patio doors. I cut myself on a piece of broken glass.

noun A glass is a container, usually made of glass and without a handle, for cold drinks. Would you like a glass of orange? I'd already drunk three glasses of wine. I bought a set of six wine glasses. You can hire glasses from the bottle shop.
glasses A pair of glasses is a pair of spectacles. Now, where did I put my glasses? I think I need new glasses.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective glass ...a glass vase.

form.definition: verb If something gleams, it reflects light, especially because it is highly polished. He polished the silver until it gleamed.
noun A gleam is a pale reflected light. The gleam of polished silver caught our eye.
noun A gleam is also a flash or glimpse of something. There's still a gleam of hope. A gleam of triumph came into his eyes.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective gleaming I want you to get this place gleaming. She showed me her gleaming new toy.

form.definition: verb If you glean information, you find it out gradually after some difficulty. After many years of searching, she finally gleaned some facts about her brother's final days. I gleaned from the report that they're not really very keen to go ahead.

noun Glee is a feeling of great joy and excitement that things are happening as you want them to. The boy jumped up and down with glee. The journalists reported the minister's downfall with malicious glee.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective gleeful

dictionary.entry: glibglIbglibberglibbest adjective If someone is glib, they talk readily without really knowing or caring very much about the subject. Her glib words didn't comfort me as they lacked all sincerity. He's got a glib answer to everything. He antagonised them as he was far too glib. ... WORD FAMILYadverb glibly noun glibness

form.definition: verb When a plane or bird glides through the air, it moves without being powered by the engine or flapping its wings. The pilot cut the engine and glided down to land in the field.

verb If you glide somewhere, you move there smoothly and as if without effort. The snake glided through the long grass. The bride and groom glided across the dance floor. The waiter glided to my side with my coat.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun glide She moved across the ice in an elegant glide.

form.definition: noun A glimmer is a very faint and often unsteady light. It was hard to read by the glimmer of the candle.
noun A glimmer is also a faint sign or suggestion of something. There still seemed to be a glimmer of life in the body.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb glimmer

form.definition: noun A glimpse is a quick look that doesn't give you enough time to notice any details of what you see. I caught a glimpse of their messy bedroom as I passed. I only got a glimpse of the men, I couldn't really describe them. She agreed to let me have a glimpse of her wedding dress.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb glimpse We glimpsed the accident as we drove by. I glimpsed an envelope on her desk.

form.definition: verb If something glints, it reflects a beam of light and attracts your attention. The blade of the knife glinted in his hand.
verb If someone's eyes glint, they show a flash of emotion. His eyes glinted with anger.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun glint We could see the glint of water through the trees.

form.definition: verb If something glistens, it reflects light, especially because it is smooth and shiny. Often it is wet. I brushed the horse's smooth coat until it glistened. The wet road glistened under the street lights. Dew glistened on the grass.
verb If something glitters, it sparkles brightly. The large diamond glittered on his finger as he moved his hand. Her eyes glittered with excitement.
noun Glitter is a glamorous image that something has. The thing appears to be very attractive. Some country folk hate the glitter of the big city.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun glitter ...the glitter of sunlight on a lake.

form.definition: verb If you gloat, you take great satisfaction in your own success or other people's failure. Paula gloated over June's defeat at the election for school captain.
noun A globe is a ball-shaped map of the earth. Turn the globe until you find Australia.

noun A globe is a hollow, glass ball that you attach to an electric light fitting. It produces light when you press the light switch. Another word for this is bulb. You need a 40 watt globe for this desk lamp.
the globe You can refer to the earth as the globe. Megan's travels took her all over the globe.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective global

form.definition: adjective When you are gloomy, you feel unhappy or depressed. No wonder he's gloomyhe's just been retrenched from his job. The outlook for the economy is gloomy at the moment. It was a gloomy winter day when I left.
adjective It is gloomy when there isn't much light and things are hard to see. By now it was getting gloomy, so we decided to go home. I hate having to go to work while it's still gloomy out.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun gloom The news reports are full of gloom. Why are you sitting alone in the gloom?

form.definition: adjective If something is glorious, it is splendid and worthy of celebration. Australia has now won the glorious total of nine gold medals. On Anzac Day especially we remember our glorious dead.

adjective If something is glorious, it is very impressive or enjoyable. The weekend weather was glorious. She has glorious golden curls. It was glorious just to relax at last. They served the most glorious pavlova.

noun Glory is the fame and honour that you gain from an outstanding achievement. There's nothing to match the glory of being an Olympic champion. She came top in the whole state and was crowned with glory. These brave lads won glory on the battlefield.

A glory is a feature of something that is especially advantageous or wonderful. The glory of the scheme is the low initial payment. This 14-day tour will introduce you to some of Australia's greatest glories.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See glorious.

form.definition: noun Gloss is the surface shine that something has. The table has lost its gloss where you've put the damp towels on it.

gloss over If you gloss something over, you cover it up or pretend that it is not important. Have you noticed how he always glosses over his mistakes? The report glossed over the disastrous beginning to the project. Her condition was glossed over as the result of fatigue.
gloss paint Gloss paint dries with a shiny surface which you can wipe over if it gets dirty. You usually use it on woodwork, such as the doors and window frames, when you are painting a house.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective gloss Do you want a gloss or matt finish on your photographs?adjective glossy This shampoo will make your hair glossy.

form.definition: noun A glossary is an alphabetically arranged list of words with their meanings or translations. There's a three-page glossary of technical terms at the back of the book. All the words needed for the exercises can be found in the glossary.

noun Gloves are garments which you wear on your hands to protect them from the cold or when you do a specific job. They are shaped like your handseach one has four fingers and a thumb. I always wear plastic gloves to do the washing up. Have you seen my gardening gloves? The hair dye comes with a pair of disposable gloves to use when applying it.

glove box The glove box in a car is a small compartment set into the dashboard. You can use it to store small objects such as gloves, sunglasses, pens and road maps. Would you get me a tissue out of the glove box, please?
verb If something glows, it gives out a steady light. The fence was painted with luminous paint to glow in the dark.
verb If you glow with happiness or health, you look very lively, cheerful and well.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun glow The glow of the coals in the grate was the only light in the dark room.adjective glowing She gave a glowing report of your success.

form.definition: noun Glucose is a type of sugar which is produced naturally in plants and animals and which is the main energy source for most living cells.

noun Glucose is a food derived from starch, consisting of a mixture of sugars. It is used in many processed foods and you can also buy it in tablet form or as a syrup or powder. It is quickly absorbed into the bloodstream to give you energy. The label on the honey says it has added glucose.
noun Glue is a substance which is used to stick things together, often to repair them because they are broken. I bought a tube of glue to mend the broken chair.
glued to If you say that someone is glued to something, you mean that their entire attention is focused on that thing. Michael didn't hear me callhe's glued to the television as usual.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb glue It's only glued together. I glued the picture onto the cardboard.

form.definition: adjective If someone is glum, they are miserable and depressed. Petra's glum because she missed out on an interview for that job she wanted. This dull weather really makes me glum.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb glumly She eyed the mess glumly.

form.definition: noun A glut of something is too much of it. There's a glut of potatoes on the market.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb glut (gluts, glutted, glutting) Some people think that Australia is glutted with politicians.

form.definition: noun A glutton is a greedy person who eats too much. What a glutton that guy is! Did you see how many chocolates he ate?

glutton for punishment If you say that someone is a glutton for punishment, you mean that they seem to enjoy doing things that you find unpleasant. She's taking two evening classes nowtalk about a glutton for punishment! ... WORD FAMILYadjective gluttonous No amount of exercise could make up for her gluttonous eating habits.noun gluttony His weight problem is due to sheer gluttony.
verb If you gnash your teeth, you grind them together, usually because you are angry or frustrated. I was left gnashing my teeth as the car sped away.

verb If you gnaw something, you bite and chew on it repeatedly. The dog was in the corner gnawing at its bone. The mice gnawed through the rope. The creature had gnawed its own leg off in an attempt to escape from the trap.
If something gnaws at you, it is constantly on your mind and you can't forget it. Resentment kept gnawing away at her.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective gnawing I felt a gnawing pain. Few people today have known gnawing hunger.

form.definition: abbreviation for gross national product. This is the total value of the goods and services produced by a country in a year.

verb If you go somewhere, you move or travel from one place to another. I'm going to Melbourne next week. He's gone to buy bread. Does this train go to Epping? I went over to the door. Let's go and play tennis.
verb If you go somewhere, you visit that place regularly. Where did you go to school? I went to Macquarie University. I stopped going to church in my teens.

verb If something goes somewhere, it leads or extends there. The Pacific Highway goes up the coast to Brisbane. The picture rail goes all the way around the room. The belt's too short to go around my waist.
verb If something goes somewhere, it belongs there or that's its usual spot. The plates go on the second shelf. This piece of the jigsaw must go there. There's a hood to go over your head.
verb If a vehicle goes, it is in motion. How fast does this car go? It was hard to tell if it was our train or the other one that was going.
verb If a piece of machinery goes, it works properly. Our fridge is twenty years old, but it's still going. The watch should go for over a year before you need to change the battery.
verb If you go, you leave or depart. I'd better goit's getting late. They've already been and gone. I had to go before the end of the meeting.
verb If something goes, it disappears. My pen was here a minute ago but now it's gone. I can't get this cold to go.
verb If something such as food or money goes, it is used up. Half my income goes on rent. A new delivery came in the morning and went by lunchtime.

verb If someone or something goes a certain way, they become like that. Her hair went white overnight. He's going bald. He'll go mad when he finds out. The sheets went pink in the wash. Bake until it goes brown on top. Your dinner's going cold!

verb In some phrases, if you say someone or something goes a certain way, you mean they remain as they were before. It's disturbing to see a guilty man go free. If you won't eat your supper, you'll have to go hungry. His presence went unnoticed. I can't let that assertion go unchallenged.
verb If an event goes well or goes badly, it is successful or unsuccessful. The meeting went well. How have things been going?
verb If you say how something like a song goes, you quote some words from it. Do you know the poem that goes 'In the morning the fish remember the night'?
verb If an alarm goes, it makes a noise.
noun A go is an attempt to do something. He finally passed the test at his third go. I don't know much about fishing, but I'll give it a go.
noun If it's your go, it's your turn to do something. Let Hamish have a go on the swing now, Kyle. If you throw a six you get an extra go. That looks fun, can I have a go?
get going If you get going or get something going, you start an action of some sort. I want to get going on the painting before seven tomorrow. OK, let's get this meal goingI'm hungry.

go about If you go about something, you take the steps needed to deal with it. How would you go about this task? I don't know how to go about getting a passport. Painting is easy if you go about it the right way.
go after If you go after something, you make it your goal. You try to obtain it. Yussuf's going after the drama prize. If you want a career in advertising, you really have to go after it.

go against (a) If you go against someone's wishes or instructions, you don't do what they want or tell you to. They went against my orders and cancelled the delivery. She went against my advice to wait another week.

(b) If something goes against your principles or your character, it doesn't seem right or come naturally to you. It goes against my principles to reject a person in trouble. It went against my nature to be so outspoken, but I forced myself.

21 go ahead (a) If you go ahead with a plan, you continue to do what you intended. They decided not to go ahead with the project after reviewing the costs involved. It looks as if the renovations will go ahead at last.

(b) If you tell someone to go ahead, you are inviting them to speak or giving them permission to do something. 'I'd like to ask a question.' 'Go ahead.' 'May I just fetch my bag?' 'Go ahead.' Go ahead whenever you're readyI've finished with the printer now.

go along If you go along with someone or something, you agree to plans that have been made and adapt yourself to fit in with them. Don't do anything special for me, just carry on as normal and I'll go along with you. He seemed happy to go along with what I suggested. She refused to go along with the deception.

go around If an illness is going around, a lot of people are catching it. There's a nasty flu bug going around the office at the moment. She's very unhealthyshe always catches anything that's going around.

go back on If you go back on what you have promised, you don't do what you said you would. I make it a point of honour never to go back on my word. But you said you'd take the children to the zooyou can't go back on it now or they'll be terribly disappointed.
go by When time goes by, it passes. I felt more confident as time went by. I was shocked to realise that three months had gone by. After a week had gone by with no contact, I began to worry.

go down with If you go down with an illness, you catch it and are unable to do the things you normally do. Of course, on the first day of my holiday I went down with a cold. We'll be busy todaythree members of the department are absent because they've gone down with flu.
go for If you go for something, you approve of it or are enthusiastic about it. I didn't really go for his suggestion of delaying a month. A day at the beach? I could go for that!
go in When the sun goes in, clouds pass over it so that it is less bright and hot for a while. The sun went in and I got up to fetch a cardigan.

go in for If you go in for something, you choose to do it or use it regularly or as a normal thing. In my day we didn't go in for divorce. She certainly goes in for some very strange costumes! Lately I've been going in for a swim in the middle of the day.

go into If you go into something, you discuss it in some detail. Let's not go into all that againI thought we'd decided to take turns. You need to go into the causes a bit more, as well as the results.

go off (a) If you go off someone or something, you lose interest and aren't so keen on them as before. I've gone off Rosie since she was so mean to Kyle. By the time we got to the beach I'd gone off the idea of surfing.
(b) If a bomb or a siren goes off, it explodes or begins to sound.

32 go on (a) If you go on doing something or go on with something, you continue to do it. He went on reading when I came in. Hamid decided to go on with his studies after all. Go on! I can't wait to hear the end of the story.
(b) If someone goes on about something, they talk a lot and bore or irritate other people. She's always going on about her family. OK, we get the idea, there's no need to go on!
(c) If you tell someone to go on, you are urging or daring them to do something. Go on, try itit's really delicious. Go on, stand up for yourself! Go on then, tell hersee if I care!
33 go out If you go out with someone, you are dating them. Sara and Luke have been going out for a couple of months now. Are you going out with anyone at the moment?

go over (a) If you go over something, you repeat or summarise what you've been saying about a topic. Could you just go over the bit about prepositions again? At the beginning of each class I take a few minutes to go over what we did last time.

(b) If you go over something, you look or read through it to check it or to refresh your memory. I went over all my calculations again, but I couldn't find the error. It's a good idea to go over your notes from each lecture while it's still fresh in your mind.
go through (a) If you go through something, you look or read through it to check it. I went through my essay once more to check the spelling and grammar.
(b) If you go through something, you search the contents of it to find something. My mother used to go through my pockets looking for drugs. We'll have to go through the file for the receipt.
(c) If you go through an amount of money, you spend it. I go through about $50 a week on food. When Amos lost his job, he went through his savings in about six months.
(d) If you go through a difficult or unhappy time, you experience it. You endure it. Colin has been through a lot latelyhis marriage has ended and his business has collapsed.

go under If a business goes under, it fails. It ceases trading or becomes bankrupt. Many small businesses have gone under during the recession. After struggling for a year, we finally went under with debts of over $20 000.
37 go with If something goes with something else, it matches it or is suitable with it. Do these shoes go with this dress?

go without (a) If you go without something, you do not have it. You have to cope without it. For months doctors in the war zone have gone without vital drugs. During Ramadan we go without food during the daylight hours. (b) If you go without, you do not have the things you need. As a child he often had to go without.
have a go (a) If you have a go at doing something, you try to do it. Even though I didn't succeed, at least I had a go. Have a go of this new machineit's so fast!
(b) If someone has a go at you, they attack or criticise you. June's always having a go at Hui-Ling because she's jealous of her.

noun The goal is the place where you have to get the ball in order to score in various sports. In football and hockey, you have to kick or hit it between two upright posts; in basketball and netball you have to throw it through a hoop.
noun When you get the ball into this place, you score a goal. The young forward kicked two goals in the first half of the match.
noun A goal is also any aim or objective that you have. My goal is to lose five kilos in a month.
noun The goalkeeper is the player, in various sports, whose role is to defend the goal and prevent the opposing side from scoring.
noun A goat is a small animal with horns. Goats live in mountain areas and can be kept on farms.
verb If you gobble your food, you eat very quickly. She gobbled her dinner in less than five minutes and rushed out again. Don't gobble like that, or you'll get indigestion.
noun A god is an invisible being who has power over part or all of the universe. The disease was taken to be a punishment from the gods. Mars was the Roman god of war.
noun You can talk about what is most important in someone's life as their god. She made financial success her god.
God In religions that believe in only one god, this god is usually referred to as God (with a capital letter, like a name).
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See divine.

form.definition: verb If you goggle at someone, you stare at them in surprise. I couldn't help goggling when Rosa walked in with her weird new boyfriend. What are you goggling at? Are you looking for trouble, mate?

goggles You can wear goggles to protect your eyes when you swim. People also wear goggles when they work with machines that make sparks. Security guards wear them in case they get acid thrown in their face. Mountain climbers also wear them.
noun Gold is a valuable, yellow metal found in deposits in the ground. It is mined and used to make expensive jewellery and coins. It is also used as an international currency.
noun Coins or other objects made of this metal are also called gold. The miser was counting his gold. The museum has a fine exhibit of the gold discovered in the tombs.
noun Gold is the colour of gold, with a metallic finish. The title was written in gold on a red background.
adjective Gold is a bright, yellow colour. The Australian national colours are green and gold.
noun Something precious or desirable can be called gold. A reliable personal assistant is pure gold. Rupert has a heart of gold. The baby's been as good as gold while you were out.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective gold ...a gold ring. ...gold paint. ...a green and gold uniform.

form.definition: adjective A golden object looks very much like gold or has a bright yellow colour. ...a golden brooch. ...golden sand.
noun Golden syrup is a sweet, thick syrup made from sugar. It is often used in desserts and sauces, or spread on bread like honey.
noun If you say that something is a goldmine, you mean that it is very successful and produces large profits. This hot summer's been a real goldmine as we've sold so many cold drinks.

noun Golf is a game in which you have to hit a small hard ball into a series of holes in the ground, using sticks called clubs. You start a long way away from each hole and count how many times you have to hit the ball before it goes in. How about a game of golf? I like to play golf at weekends.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective golf ...a golf course. ...a golf tournament. ...a golf pro.noun golfer

form.definition: verb Gone is the past participle of go.
noun Gonorrhoea is a contagious disease which causes a painful discharge from the sexual organs.

adjective If something is good, it is pleasant or enjoyable. I went to a good party last night. Did you have a good time? The weather's been good lately. That's good news! This soup is really good. I couldn't hope for anything better.

adjective If something is good, it is of a high standard or quality. Maria got a good mark for her essay. I'll change into something better if we're going out. The movie wasn't very good, but it was fun.

adjective If something is good, it is suitable or appropriate. This is a good car for city driving. We made a good choicethe cafe was excellent. That's a good ideawe'll do it that way. This is a good one to start withit's quite easy.
adjective If someone is good, they are morally virtuous. She's a good person really, just a little wild. I try to be a good neighbour and not make too much noise.
adjective If a child is good, they are well-behaved. The twins had been good all day, so I gave them a lolly each. Beth was always a very good child. You be good now, or we'll go straight home!
adjective If you say that you are good, you mean that you are in good health or that things are going quite well for you. 'How are you, Peter?' 'Good, thanks.'

adjective If you are good at something, you do it skilfully or successfully. I'm not very good at finding my way around. Which subject are you best at. He's a good tennis player. Margaret's a really good listener. You've been a good friend to me.
noun Good is what is morally right. He was torn between good and evil.
noun Good is what is pleasant or advantageous. You have to accept the bad as well as the good in life.
for good For good means 'permanently' or 'for ever'. I first visited Australia in 1990 and I came here for good last year. There, hopefully that should fix it for good.

for your own good If something is for your own good, it is to your advantage or benefit. He should lose weight for his own good. I'm telling you this for your own good, so you know where you need to improve.

good on you You can say good on you to someone if you want to encourage them or show your support for them in some important decision they have made. 'I'm going to take up swimming to get fit.' 'Good on you.'
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See goodness.

form.definition: interjection You say goodbye to someone when one of you leaves, or you end a conversation on the telephone. Goodbye! See you later! Thanks for calling. Goodbye!
form.note: ... NOTEIn informal language this is often shortened to bye.

form.definition: say goodbye If you say goodbye to someone, you take your leave of them. I'll leave you two alone to say goodbye to each other.
If you say goodbye to something, you give up hope of it. Her father's death meant she had to say goodbye to her dreams of college. You can say goodbye to ever seeing him again.
noun Someone's goodness is their high moral character. I've never doubted his fundamental goodness. All of us have both goodness and evil within us.
noun The goodness in food is its nutritional value. Boiling vegetables for too long destroys all their goodness.

interjection Goodness and goodness gracious and goodness me are mild exclamations of surprise. Goodness, I wasn't expecting you back so soon. Goodness gracious, however did you get so dirty? Goodness me, you've certainly grown!
noun Your goods are your possessions. It'll take a couple of weeks to pack up all our goods.
noun Goods are things that are bought and sold. The electrical goods are at the back of the shop. The goods are taken to the port and loaded onto ships.
noun A goose is a large farm bird with a long neck and webbed feet.

wild goose chase If you send someone on a wild goose chase, you get them to do something which is useless or unlikely to succeed. She sent us off on a wild goose chase to track down his relatives interstate.
noun A gorge is a narrow valley between mountains, often with a river running along the bottom.
verb If you gorge yourself, you eat large quantities of food. I really gorged myself over Christmasnow it's time to go on a diet.

adjective If someone or something is gorgeous, they are very attractive or desirable. You look really gorgeous in that dress. She gave me a box of the most gorgeous chocolates. What gorgeous weather we're having!
interjection Gosh is a very mild exclamation of surprise. Gosh, it's later than I thoughtwe'd better go.
noun Gossip is talk about other people and their private lives which may or may not be true. Have you heard the latest gossip about Jo? The gossip is that he was passed over for promotion.
noun A gossip is a person who enjoys talking about other people's private lives and spreading rumours. Don't tell your troubles to Danehe's a terrible gossip.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb gossip

form.definition: verb Got is the past tense and past participle of get.

have got If you have got something, you possess it or have it at your disposal. I've got one brother and three sisters. Have you got a pair of scissors I could borrow? Have you got a moment? There's something I want to ask you. That's a nasty cold you've got.
noun A gouge is a sharp, curved tool which you use for digging out bits from a piece of wood.
gouge out If you gouge something out, you scoop it out using something sharp. I used a heated spoon to gouge the ice-cream out of the tub.
noun A gourmet is someone who enjoys fine food and knows a lot about different types of food. The new delicatessen is a gourmet's paradise.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective gourmet They do a new range of gourmet pies.

form.definition: noun Gout is a disease which causes painful swelling of the smaller joints, especially in your toes.

verb Whoever governs a country is responsible for its internal and external affairs. They make laws and manage the economy. The country is governed by a military dictatorship. To govern effectively, the party will need a clear majority in the House of Representatives.
verb If something governs something else, it controls or limits it. What you can do to your home is governed by the council's building regulation. His state of health governs how active he can be.

noun A government is the group of people who govern a country. In Australia, the Federal Government is elected by the people every three years. The party with the most members is able to form a government. The Government is threatening to raise taxes again.

noun Government is the running of a country or a smaller unit such as a state or borough. Does having a lot of minor parties lead to weak government? He has extensive experience of local government, having been a councillor for over ten years.
noun In each Australian state, the representative of the British monarch is called the Governor.

dictionary.entry:
Governor-GeneralgV v@n@-`dZEnr@l (plural forms Governor-Generals or Governors-General
noun The Governor-General of Australia is the main representative of the British monarch.

form.definition: abbreviation for Government.
noun A gown is a formal dress worn by women on special occasions. ...a ball gown. ...a wedding gown.
noun A gown is also a type of long cloak that judges and lawyers wear in court, and graduates wear at graduation ceremonies.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See dressing gown.

form.definition: abbreviation for general practitioner. A GP is a doctor who practises family medicine and is not a specialist in any particular field. If that cough doesn't clear up soon, you should go to your GP.
abbreviation for General Post Office. This is the main post office in a city.
verb If you grab something, you snatch it very quickly or roughly. He grabbed the letter from her hands and started to read it. The mugger tried to grab my case.
verb In informal language, if you say you grab something to eat, you mean you get and eat it quickly because you're in a hurry. I won't have time for dinnerI'll grab a sandwich at the station.

verb In informal language, if you say something grabs you, you mean you are enthusiastic about it. I can't say the prospect of spending the day with him exactly grabs me. A luxury harbour cruise with four-course banquethow does that grab you?
up for grabs If something is up for grabs, it is available and people are competing to get it. The job of managing the new unit is up for grabs. Over 5000 valuable prizes are up for grabs.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun grab He made a grab at her arm.

form.definition: noun Grace is beauty and delicacy of movement. The dancers performed with great grace. She has a certain natural grace about her.
noun Grace is also a period of time that you have before you have to do something. He gave us two weeks' grace to decide. They asked for a week's grace to pay the bill.
noun Grace is also a prayer that some people say before a meal.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective graceful She sat down with a graceful movement.adverb gracefully

form.definition: adjective If someone is gracious, they are charming and courteous. Mary is a very gracious hostess. He was gracious enough to apologise when he realised his mistake.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb graciously

form.definition: verb If you grade things, you classify or sort them according to such things as quality, age or size. The sorters grade the apples by size and colour.

noun A grade is a classification. The different grades of meat are packaged in different ways. We only use the highest grade of vegetable oil. He's going for a new job with a higher grade. c noun A grade is a class of pupils who have reached a particular stage in their education. Many Australian schools use the word year for this. Simone is going into Grade 4 next year.
noun Your grade in a subject at school or college is based on the marks you get for assignments and tests. I'm hoping to get an A grade overall.
verb When teachers or examiners grade students, they assess the quality of their work. One of the things we grade the pupils on is their ability to work alone.
noun A grade is a slope. CAUTION: STEEP GRADE. TRUCKS SHOULD USE LOW GEAR.
adjective If something is gradual, it happens slowly over a long period of time. We could see a gradual deterioration in his health. There has been a gradual increase in student numbers.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb gradually I gradually lost interest in the idea.

dictionary.entry:
graduate`grAdZu:@t <for the noun; for the verb,>`grAdZu:EIt
