noun A graduate is someone who has successfully completed a degree course at a university or college. The new graduates received their certificates at the ceremony. We need a graduate for this job. She's a graduate of La Trobe University.
verb If you graduate, you receive a degree that shows you have successfully completed your course of study at a university or college. I graduated in 1995. He left the university without graduating.
... WORD FAMILYnoun graduation adjective graduate

form.definition: noun Graffiti is drawings or words that people write on walls or signs in public places. Many of the messages are rude or about politics. I saw some very clever graffiti the other day. The council is fighting a losing battle trying to keep the bridge free of graffiti.
noun A graft is a part of a plant which is cut off and attached to another plant. The two joined plants continue to grow as one.
noun A graft is a piece of healthy tissue such as skin or bone which a doctor takes from one part of your body and places in another part that is damaged.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb graft The plastic surgeon grafted skin from John's leg to his burnt arm.

form.definition: noun A grain of cereal is one seed of the plant. Grain is a lot of seeds from a cereal plant. Add salt to the water to keep the rice grains nicely separate when you boil them. The grain passes down this chute and is milled into flour. Most of the farm is planted with grain.
noun A grain of something is a small, hard piece of it. If you look at a grain of salt with a magnifying glass, you can see it has a cubic shape. I got a grain of sand in my eye.

noun The grain of a piece of wood is the way the fibres in it are arranged. You should be able to split it quite easily along the grain. I applied a wax polish to show up the attractive grain. The grain in these two panels doesn't match well.

grain of truth If you say that there is a grain of truth in a report or story, you mean that it's partly true, although it has been exaggerated or distorted. There's a grain of truth in what she says, but it's not as serious as she makes out.
noun A gram is a unit of weight, equal to one thousandth of a kilogram. The baby gained 200 grams in her first week.
form.note: ... NOTEThe abbreviation for this is g.

form.definition: noun The grammar of a language is the rules which describe how its words are formed and put together to create sentences. The grammar of English is quite different from that of most Asian languages.
noun A grammar is a book which explains all the rules for creating sentences in a language. Can you recommend a good English grammar to me?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective grammatical

form.definition: noun Gran is an informal shortened form of grandmother. My gran comes from Korea. Merry Christmas, Gran.

adjective If something is grand, it is imposing or splendid. They live in a grand house in the country. The hotel is full of servants wearing grand uniforms. They gave me a grand title, but the job was pure routine.
noun If someone is grand, they are important and wealthy. They belonged to one of the grandest families in the country. So, you're too grand now to have time for your own family?

grand total A grand total is a total obtained by adding up figures which are themselves totals of other figures. It is the final or overall total. The phrase is also used for a total obtained by adding any figures, especially if this is a low number. Tom spent $32 on souvenirs, Laura $45 and Max $21, so that's a grand total of $98. I bought three dresses and a pair of boots at the flea market for a grand total of $50.
noun A grandchild is a granddaughter or grandson. We now have thirteen grandchildrenten boys and three girls.
noun Your granddaughter is the daughter of your daughter or son.
noun Your grandfather is the father of your father or mother. In informal language, you can refer to someone's grandfather as their granddad.

adjective If something is grandiose, it is very elaborate and ambitious, but not really practical. Their renovations were far too grandiose for a house in the suburbs. He's got grandiose plans for expanding into the international market.
noun Your grandmother is the mother of your father or mother. In informal language, you can refer to someone's grandmother as their grandma.
noun A grandparent is a grandfather or grandmother. I never knew any of my grandparents.
noun Your grandson is the son of your daughter or son.

dictionary.entry: grandstandstand is a building for the spectators at a sportsground. The seats are arranged in steps or tiers, so that everyone has a good view of what is happening on the field.

form.definition: noun Granite is a very hard rock with pieces of different colours in it. It can be polished and is often used in buildings and monuments for its decorative effect.
noun A Granny Smith is a type of apple with green skin and white, juicy flesh. You can use these apples in cooking or eat them raw.

noun A grant is an amount of money given to someone by an organisation for a special purpose. They get a grant from the government to provide labour-market training for migrants. I applied for a grant to cover the cost of travel.

verb If you grant something to someone, you agree to it or give it to them, often because they have asked or applied for it. My teacher granted me an extra five days to do the essay as I'd been ill. Each family was granted $100 towards their expenses.
verb If you grant someone's request, you agree to what they ask. I reluctantly granted their request. My wish was granted when he came back unexpectedly.
noun Grapes are small, round, juicy fruit which grow in bunches on a vine. They are either green or purple in colour and can be eaten fresh or dried, or used to make wine.
noun A graph is a diagram which uses lines or curves to show figures or the relationship between quantities. The graph on the wall shows inflation over the last twelve months.

adjective If something is graphic, it is very detailed and clear. She gave us a graphic account of the birthday party. I wish he hadn't been quite so graphic about his operation. The pornography is very graphic.
adjective Graphic design is the creation of pictures and images to illustrate text or convey a message, rather than as pure art. Sam's a graphic designer in an advertising agency.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb graphically noun graphic This printer is especially good for graphics. I added a graphic of a cat.

form.definition: noun Graphite is a black substance which is a form of carbon. It is used to make the centre of lead pencils.

verb If you grapple with someone, you wrestle and struggle physically with them. The two men grappled for several minutes and one was stabbed. I grappled with the intruder, but he escaped from my clutches.
verb If you grapple with a problem, you try your best to solve it. She's been grappling with her weight problem for many years.
verb If you grasp something, you take it very firmly in your hands and hold it tightly. She grasped the rope with both hands, determined not to let go. Grasp the racquet like this.
verb If you grasp an idea, you understand it. It took him a long time to grasp what the stranger was saying. You fail to grasp the seriousness of the problem.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See grasping.noun grasp His reach exceeds his grasp. She has a sound grasp of the subject.

form.definition: adjective If someone is grasping, they are greedy and miserly. He's such a grasping personhe takes what he wants and doesn't care who suffers. I don't like his kidsthey're so grasping, always asking what presents they'll get.

noun Grass is a common plant with short, spiky leaves which grows very quickly. It is planted in parks and gardens to form lawns and playing fields. Let's have our picnic on the grass under that tree.
noun In informal language, grass is marijuana. I used to smoke grass as a student, but I wouldn't know where to get it these days.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb grass We decided to grass most of the yard.

form.definition: noun The grassroots of something is its basis or foundation. Let's get down to the grassroots of this problemthen maybe we can sort it out. She accused the party leadership of ignoring the grassroots of its support.
verb If you grate food, you shred it into small pieces or strips with a knife or a grater. Heregrate these carrots for me.
verb If something grates against something else, it scrapes against it and often makes an unpleasant noise. The chalk grated on the blackboard as he[qr wrote.
noun A grate is the part of a fireplace where you pile up the wood or coals that you burn.
verb grate on If something grates on you, it irritates you. Jean's shrill voice really grates on me.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See grater.

form.definition: adjective If you are grateful for something, you appreciate it very much and often thank someone for giving it to you. I feel the cold, so I'm very grateful for this warm weather. I'm so grateful to you for all your help. I always give them nice presents, but they never seem very grateful.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See gratitude.adverb gratefully She sank gratefully into the chair.[qr

dictionary.entry:
grater`grEIt@
noun A grater is a tool which you use to grate food. Usually it is made of metal and has a flat surface with sharp-edged holes. You scrape the food up and down the surface and pieces of it fall off through the holes.[qr

grating`grEItIN
noun A grating is a frame of metal bars which is used as a cover or guard over a drain or other opening.

form.definition: noun Gratitude is a feeling of being grateful for something. These flowers are to express my gratitude for all your help. I'd expected them to show a bit more gratitude.
noun A grave is a hole in the earth where a dead person is buried. I used to visit my mother's grave every Sunday. They uncovered a mass grave filled with the remains of victims of the dictatorship.
adjective If something is grave, it is very serious and worrying. The situation is very gravewar could break out at any time.
adjective If someone is grave, they are very quiet and serious. He's such a grave little boyI wish he'd laugh more. She tried to look grave, but collapsed in a fit of giggles.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See gravity.adverb gravely She's gravely ill.

form.definition: noun Gravel is small stones or chips of rock that are laid in driveways, paths and roads. Their house has a path of red gravel leading to the front door.
noun A graveyard is an area of land where dead people are buried. It is often situated near a church.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is cemetery.

form.definition: verb If you gravitate towards someone or something, you are drawn to them because they are attractive or interesting. People always gravitate towards him at partieshe's such a good entertainer. At first I took a wide range of courses, but later I gravitated towards history.

noun Gravity is the physical force which pulls things towards the centre of the earth. It is because of gravity that when you let go of something, it falls to the ground. In space everything floats around because there is no gravity.
noun Gravity is also the seriousness of a situation. Most people have still not woken up to the gravity of the crisis.
noun Gravy is a sauce made from the juices of cooked meat.
verb If an animal grazes, it feeds on grass and other small plants in a field. The cattle are grazing down by the creek.

verb If you graze some part of your body, you scrape it against something rough and break the skin. I grazed my elbow on the brick wall as I ran past. Pedro grazed his knees when he fell over in the playground.
verb If something grazes something else, it scrapes past it as it moves and does some damage to the surface. The other car grazed my wing. Fortunately the bullet only grazed his shoulder.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun graze This ointment is good for minor cuts and grazes.

form.definition: noun A grazier is a farmer who owns a large property supporting sheep or cattle, or both.
noun Grease is a thick, oily substance. The frying pan is full of grease from the bacon. You need to apply some grease to the joints. Raw wool is naturally waterproof because of all the grease in it.

verb If you grease something, you smear grease on it, for example to lubricate it or make it waterproof. Grease the bottom of the baking tray. I greased the lock where it was sticking. Long-distance swimmers grease themselves thoroughly as insulation against the cold.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective greasy (greasier, greasiest) My hands are all greasy. I find their chips a bit too greasy.

form.definition: adjective Something that is greaseproof, such as greaseproof paper, does not let grease pass through it. Wrap up the meat in greaseproof paper.

dictionary.entry:
greatgrEItgreatergreatest 1a adjective Great is a rather formal or old-fashioned word meaning 'big' or 'large'. The mouse was devoured by a great bird. Three great ships came sailing into the harbour. A great crowd gathered around. One night there was a great
adjective Great can also indicate a large amount or high degree of something abstract. I've got great admiration for him. They sell a great variety of food. The train was moving at great speed. She showed great courage. The effect was much greater than expected.
adjective If someone or something is great, they are important or famous. He is one of the great artists of this century. Meanwhile, on the other side of the world, great events were taking place. It's people like him that have made our country great.
adjective In informal language, if you say something is great, you mean you like it or are pleased about it. We had a great time last night. My mum's a great cook. It's great to see you again. If you can get here about five, that'll be great. Great, we'll do that then.
adjective Great is used before nouns indicating family relationships to show how many generations apart people are. For example, your great-grandmother is the mother of your grandmother and your great-great-grandmother is one generation older than that.
great big In informal language, you use great big to emphasise that something is very large and impressive. Suddenly a great big truck came speeding down the road. He gave her a great big box of chocolates.

greedy`gri:di:greediergreediest adjective If someone is greedy, they want to have as much of something as they can possibly get and they don't care if this means that other people don't have enough. 'She ate a whole tub of ice-cream and was sick.' 'Serve her right for being so greedy.' ... WORD FAMILYnoun greed adverb greedily

form.definition: noun Greek is the language of Greece.
adjective If someone or something comes from Greece, you describe them as Greek.

dictionary.entry:
greengri:ngreenergreenest 1 noun Green is the colour of leaves and grass.
adjective If fruits are green, they are not yet ripe.
adjective If someone is green, they are innocent or do not have much experience. She's very green to be out in the world by herself.
noun A green is a patch of grass in a town where people can sit and relax.
noun In golf, a green is the patch of smoothly mown grass around each hole. At the fifth hole it took me five shots just to get onto the green.
Green Party The Green Party is an Australian political party. Another name for this is the Greens.
greens In informal language, we call green vegetables such as cabbage, spinach and broccoli greens. Eat up your greensthey're very good for you.
green with envy If someone is green with envy, they are very envious of someone else. When I saw your new car, I was green with envy.
... WORD FAMILYadjective green ...a green dress.noun greenness

form.definition: noun A greengrocer is a person who sells fresh vegetables and fruit, or a shop where they are sold. My father was a greengrocer. There's a greengrocer next to the chemist.
noun A greenhouse is a structure with a glass roof and walls in which plants that need special protection are grown.
greenhouse effect The greenhouse effect is the problem of the overheating of the earth's atmosphere caused by pollution.

verb If you greet someone, you welcome or receive them somewhere, or you say hello to them when you meet. I went to the airport to greet the chairman. We've organised a small reception to greet our visitors. He greeted me as if I were his best friend. She greeted him with a nod.

verb If you greet something in a particular way, that is how you react when you become aware of it. His speech was greeted with loud jeers. Union leaders have greeted the proposal with cautious enthusiasm.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See greeting.

form.definition: noun A greeting is what you say or do when you meet someone. He lifted his hat in greeting. 'Good morning' is a rather formal greeting.
greetings If you send greetings to someone, you send them your best wishes. Greetings from all the people of Perth to our sister city.

greetings card A greetings card is a folded card which you buy and send to someone on a special occasion such as their birthday or when they get married or have a child. Usually it has a picture on the front and a printed message inside.
noun A grenade is a small explosive bomb which is thrown by hand or fired from a rifle.
noun A grevillea is an Australian native tree or shrub. There are many different species of it.
verb Grew is the past tense of grow.
noun Grey is the colour in between white and black. She was dressed in grey.
adjective If the weather is grey, it is dull and overcast. What a grey day! It looks like rain.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective grey The lead in pencils is grey.noun greyness[qr

dictionary.entry:
gridgrId
noun A grid is a pattern of parallel lines which cross each other at right angles to form squares. Maps often have a numbered grid drawn on them to make it easier to find things by looking in one particular square.
noun A grid is a frame made from lengths of metal or wood laid across each other at right angles to form square holes. There's a heavy metal grid over the hole.

form.definition: noun Grief is great sadness. He suffered enormous grief when his wife died.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb grieve She grieved for him deeply. It grieves me to see him so sick.

form.definition: noun A grievance is something that you feel angry about because you think that you have been treated unfairly. The workers presented a list of their grievances to management. He was motivated by a burning sense of grievance.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective grievance Most awards contain agreed grievance procedures.

form.definition: noun A grill is part of an oven, where you cook food such as sausages under a strong heat coming from above or below. Another word for this is griller.
verb If you grill someone about something, you question them closely. She grilled me about every detail of the party.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun grill Do you want your fish fingers grilled or fried?

form.definition: noun A grille is a framework of metal bars placed in front of something in order to protect it. There are grilles in front of all our windows to stop burglars getting in.
adjective If a situation is grim, it is extremely unpleasant or serious. Things look grimshe could die.

adjective If someone is grim, they are very serious because they are worried or upset about something or have an unpleasant task to do. Joe looked grimsomething terrible must have happened. He greeted us with a grim smile.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb grimly noun grimness

form.definition: noun A grimace is a twisted expression on your face that you make because you are upset, afraid, angry or in pain. He made a grimace of disgust at the suggestion.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb grimace She grimaced with rage.

form.definition: noun Grime is dirt that collects over a long period of time. We scraped away the grime in the old oven.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective grimy

form.definition: verb When you grin, you smile broadly. He couldn't stop grinning when he heard he'd won the prize.

grin and bear it If you grin and bear it, you make the most of a bad situation because you know there's nothing you can do about it. There's no point in complaining about the bad weatherwe'll just have to grin and bear it.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun grin A cheery grin lit up his face.

form.definition: verb If you grind something, you crush it into fine powder. I ground the nuts in my new food processor. This is where the wheat is ground into flour.
verb If you grind something, you wear it away by rubbing it against a hard, rough surface. The dentist ground down my jagged tooth until it was nice and smooth.

verb If you grind your teeth, you grate them together. This often happens when you're angry or frustrated about something. Even though I was really cross, I could only sit there and grind my teeth. Elsa often grinds her teeth in her sleep.

verb If a machine or vehicle grinds or grinds along, it operates or moves very slowly and often makes a lot of noise. We could hear the car grinding slowly up the drive. The computer was still grinding through the figures.
noun If you say that something is a grind, you mean that it is very boring or unpleasant. Housework is a real grind. It's nice to get away from the daily grind for a bit.
come to a grinding halt If something comes to a grinding halt, it stops because of some problem. My work came to a grinding halt when the computer broke down.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun grinder

form.definition: verb If you grip something, you hold onto it tightly. She gripped my arm as he approached. This clamp grips the rope and prevents it from slipping. The crocodile gripped me in its jaws and dragged me under water.
verb If something grips you, you are very interested in it. He was totally gripped by the exciting performance.

get a grip on yourself If you get a grip on yourself, you make a determined effort to control your feelings and behaviour. Get a grip on yourself! If we panic now, we're in real trouble. It's pointless and cruel to tell a depressed person to get a grip on themselves.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun grip I was caught in his powerful grip. Our boss keeps a tight grip on the finances.adjective gripping She told us some gripping stories about her adventures.

form.definition: verb If you gripe about something, you complain or grumble about it constantly. Jack always gripes about the way his boss treats him.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun gripe My main gripe is the way they never say thank you.

form.definition: adjective If something is grisly, it is extremely horrible and disgusting. He was arrested for a series of grisly murders. The investigators made a grisly discovery in the cellar. She loves grisly tales about ghosts and revenge.
noun Gristle is a hard, rubbery substance sometimes found in meat. I couldn't eat my steak because it was full of gristle.
noun Grit is small specks of stone or sand which are blown about in the wind. I've got some grit in my eye. Make sure the surface is free of dust and grit before you paint it.
noun In informal language, grit is the strength and determination someone shows in trying to achieve something. That kid's got a lot of gritshe never gives up.

grit your teeth If you grit your teeth, you close your jaw firmly. Often this is a sign that you are displeased about something but have to endure or put up with it. Don't give up the course nowjust grit your teeth for the last few weeks. I gritted my teeth and welcomed her to the department.
verb If a child grizzles about something, they cry and whinge in a very irritating way. That little boy never stops grizzling.
verb If someone groans, they cry out with a long, low sound because they are in great distress or pain. The injured soldier lay groaning on a blood-soaked mattress.

verb If you groan about something, you make a sound or say something to show that you are not pleased about it. They all groaned when I told them they'd have to work late. He's always groaning about his income tax.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun groan He let out a groan of pain. The announcement was greeted with groans.

form.definition: noun A grocer is a rather old-fashioned name for a person who sells groceries and other household supplies, or a shop where these things are sold. These days even a small shop that sells such things is often called a supermarket.

noun Groceries are items of food that you buy regularly and generally keep a stock of, such as bread, milk, sugar, eggs, and tinned foods. Meat and vegetables are not usually counted as groceries. I'm going to the post officeshall I get any groceries on the way?
noun In informal language, grog is alcoholic drink. I had too much grog last night. We'd better buy some grog to take to the party.
adjective If you are groggy, you are not fully alert or able to function normally. She was still groggy from the operation. I had flu last week and was groggy for three days.

noun Your groin is the place where your legs join on to your abdomen. Sometimes this word is used as a polite way of referring to a man's genitals. He was kicked in the groin during the football match.
form.note: ... SEE THE PICTUREat body.

form.definition: noun A groom is someone who looks after horses. 2 noun A groom is a bridegroom.
verb If you groom an animal, you clean it by brushing and combing its coat.
verb If you groom yourself, you make sure you are looking clean, smart and tidy.
A groomsman is a male friend of the bridegroom who helps at a wedding.
noun A groove is a long, narrow cut or track in a surface. The projecting nail made a nasty groove in the paintwork. Slide the peg along this groove.
noun If you are stuck in a groove, everything in your life is routine and familiar. Ten-Hu feels he's in a groovehe needs a new job, or maybe a new hobby.

verb If you grope for something, you feel about for it with your hands because you can't see it. She groped in her pocket for the keys. He was groping around in the dark trying to find the light switch.

adjective If something is gross, it is very extreme and unacceptable. They were guilty of the gross neglect of their children. He has been done a gross injustice. There have been several gross breaches of the regulations lately.

adjective If someone or something is gross, they are crude and offensive or extremely disgusting and unpleasant. His language is far too gross. The movie's humour is pretty gross at times. She's got some gross habits, such as picking her nose. They served this really gross raw fish stew.
adjective If someone is gross, they are very fat.

adjective Gross refers to the total amount of something. It can describe a sum of money before any deductions or costs are removed, or a weight including both the packaging and contents or the vehicle and load. The opposite of this is net. Last year we made a gross profit of $200 000. I earn $500 gross. The gross weight of the parcel is 2 kg. The truck has a gross weight of 12 tonnes.
noun A gross is a group or case of 144 things. He bought a gross of four-centimetre nails for building the deck.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb gross The business grossed $750 000 in its first year of operation.adverb grossly He was grossly negligent.

form.definition: adjective If something is grotesque, it is shocking and immoral. The slaying of innocent animals to satisfy human vanity is grotesque.
adjective In informal language, if you say that someone is grotesque, you mean that they are very ugly. Reba's new boyfriend's grotesque, but she seems to like him.
adjective In informal language, if you say something is grotty, you mean it is shabby and dirty or in a poor state of repair. We stayed in a grotty hotel near the station. ...grotty hands.
verb If someone grouches about something, they complain about it in an unpleasant way. He's always grouching about his mother-in-law, but he's happy enough to live in her house.
noun A grouch is a bad-tempered person who is always complaining and finding fault with things. Don't be such a grouchwe'll have a good time when we get there.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective grouchy (grouchier, grouchiest)

form.definition: verb Ground is the past tense and past participle of grind.
noun The ground is the surface of the earth which we stand and walk on. His glass fell to the ground and shattered. Spread the picnic rug on the dry ground over there.

noun The ground is also the layer of soil and rock that covers the surface of the earth. The ground is easier to dig when it's damp from rain. You need to hit the tent pegs about 10 cm into the ground. There is said to be buried treasure somewhere under the ground.

noun Ground is the topics that you study or discuss. We've already covered most of this ground. You're on dangerous ground raising the question of loyalty. I know I'm on solid ground when we talk about electronics.

noun A ground is an area of open space set aside for a particular purpose. These are Australian fishing grounds. The local cricket ground is maintained by the council. The house is surrounded by extensive grounds.
verb When a ship or boat grounds, it runs up onto the shore or gets stuck on a reef or rock. We grounded on the coral reef and had to be towed off by another boat.

verb If someone is grounded, they have limits put on their movements as a punishment for breaking a rule. Usually they are not allowed to go out for recreation during a certain period. Wal's father's grounded him for a week for getting home so late last night.
When a plane or a pilot is grounded, they are not allowed to fly. All planes are grounded because of poor visibility. Brad was grounded after he failed the medical examination.
gain ground If you gain ground, you become more successful in a competitive situation. The Opposition has been gaining ground in the latest opinion polls.

grounding A grounding in a subject is the basic skills or knowledge. I'd had a solid grounding in Indonesian at school, so it wasn't hard to get by. The eight-week course aims to give you a grounding in metal-working techniques.
lose ground If you lose ground, you become less successful in a competitive situation. His aggressive attitude lost him ground with the interviewers.

stand your ground If you stand your ground, you refuse to give in or change your mind about something. The soldiers stood their ground against the enemy attack. He believed he was right, so he stood his ground in spite of heavy criticism.
noun Groundwork is the early work or the preparation you do which acts as a basis for further work. The project should move along faster now we've completed the groundwork.

noun A group is a number of people or things that go together or have something in common. A group of children got onto the bus. Form groups of four for this exercise. This change brought a new group of problems. What's your blood group?
verb If you group things, you divide them into categories. We'll group these orders according to the type of product.
verb If you group things together, you classify them in the same way. You assign them to the same category. I objected to being grouped with the more junior employees.
verb If you group things, you arrange their position in relation to each other. The photographer grouped us for the wedding pictures.

group certificate noun A group certificate is a statement which your employer gives you at the end of the financial year. It states your total earnings in the year, the tax you've paid and your superannuation contributions.
noun Grout is a substance which you use to fill in the gaps between tiles. You apply it as a paste and it becomes solid when it dries.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb grout

form.definition: verb If you grovel, you behave in a very humble way towards someone. You may be afraid of them or you may want them to do something for you. They really make you grovel before they give you any more money. I can't stand the way he grovels to the boss.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective grovelling He issued a grovelling apology for the blunder.

form.definition: verb If someone or something grows, they get bigger or increase. The baby's grown a lot since I last saw it. The town has grown rapidly. The number of students has grown each year. Fears are growing for the safety of the missing student.
verb If you grow mentally, your knowledge and experience develop. She has grown in her understanding of other people and their problems.
verb If you grow a plant, you raise it and look after it. I grow vegetables in my garden.

verb If something is growing somewhere, it is alive and developing. Grass grew between the cracks. They've got a vine growing up the side of the house. He's got a tumour growing on his neck. Is it true that your fingernails grow after you're dead?

verb If someone or something grows into a particular state, they become like that. I grew impatient with his lies. I could see she was growing angry. It's growing cold in here. I must goit's growing late.
grow up (a) A child grows up as it gets older and becomes an adult. I grew up on a farm. The girls are growing up fast.

(b) If you tell someone to grow up, you want them to stop being foolish or naive. It's about time he grew up and started taking his responsibilities seriously. Grow up! Of course the results are all fixed in advance.
grow out of (a) If you grow out of clothes, you grow so much that they come to be too small for you. I had to wear old clothes that my sister had grown out of.

(b) If you grow out of a habit, you stop doing it as you become older and more mature. Don't worry about Maryse sucking her thumbshe'll grow out of it eventually. ... WORD FAMILYadjective See grown.noun See growth.noun grower These pest-resistant varieties are popular with commercial growers.adjective growing Pollution is a growing problem. They watched with growing concern.
verb If an animal growls, it makes a low, rumbling sound in its throat as a warning signal or because it is angry. The dog growls every time I get near the gate.
verb If a person growls, they say something in a rough, angry way. He growls at her every time she asks him a question.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun growl

form.definition: verb Grown is the past tense of grow.
adjective A grown man or woman is an adult. She's divorced, with three grown children. Mother, I'm a grown woman nowI can make my own decisions. The horrific sight made grown soldiers cry.
noun The growth of something is its increase and development. There are signs of growth in the economy. They are concerned about world population growth. I am interested in personal growth.
noun A growth is a tumour or a mass of tissue. He had an enormous growth on his upper arm. Cartilage is a bone-like growth found in the joints.

noun A grub is the soft, young form of an insect. It looks like a short worm. To my disgust there was a grub in my apple! The boiled grubs have a creamy texture and are an excellent source of protein.
noun In informal language, grub is food. I hope we've got enough grub for the barbecue.
adjective If something is grubby, it is slightly dirty. Don't touch the tablecloth with your grubby fingers! I washed the shirt twice, but it still looks grubby.

noun A grudge is a lasting feeling of resentment because you think you've been badly or unfairly treated. He still bears a grudge against his brother for being mean to him as a child. The police asked if there was anyone with a grudge against the murder victim. I don't hold grudges.

adjective If you are grudging, you don't want to do something, but you are forced to and so you do it in a mean way. He was very grudging about letting us have the time off. She eventually made a grudging apology.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb See begrudge.adverb grudgingly

form.definition: adjective If something is gruelling, it is very strenuous and exhausting, and lasts a long time. We played a gruelling tennis match that went to five sets. After the gruelling 30-hour flight, I just wanted a bath and bed.
adjective If something is gruesome, it is horrific and disgusting. The rescue workers faced a gruesome scene at the crash site. We saw a gruesome horror movie last night.
adjective A gruff voice is low and rather harsh.
adjective If someone is gruff, they seem rather fierce and unfriendly. Don't be put off by his gruff mannerhe's very kind once you get to know him.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb gruffly noun gruffness

form.definition: verb If you grumble about something, you complain about it, but not in a very loud or forceful way. They were grumbling about how they were overworked and underpaid. We can't really grumblethe weather was lovely for the first two weeks of the holiday.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun grumble My only grumble is that the portions were rather small.

form.definition: adjective If someone is grumpy, they are bad-tempered and irritableeither because they are not in a good mood, or because that is their character. I'm always grumpy first thing in the morning. The caretaker is a rather grumpy old man.
verb When a pig grunts, it makes a low, rough sound.
verb If someone grunts, they make a low sound instead of speaking, often because they are annoyed about something. She just grunted when I asked her if I could borrow her car again.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun grunt

form.definition: noun A guarantee is a promise by a manufacturer that if their product doesn't last or work properly for at least a certain period of time, it will be replaced or repaired free of charge. Our new fridge has a five-year guarantee. Is the watch still under guarantee? ... A SIMILAR WORDfor this is warranty.b noun A guarantee is a promise or assurance that something will definitely happen. The money will be with you by the end of the weekyou have my personal guarantee of that. On her current form she should win easily, but of course there are no guarantees.
verb If you guarantee something, you promise that it will definitely happen. I guarantee you'll love this movie. I'll try and be home by six, but I can't guarantee it.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb guarantee All our products are guaranteed for two years.

form.definition: verb If you guard someone or something, you protect them from harm or damage. Their alsatian dog guards the house and grounds. The gang leader was guarded by two burly thugs. This sheet will guard the floor from splashes.
verb If you guard someone, you watch them to make sure that they don't escape. The prisoner was closely guarded night and day.
noun A guard is a person whose job it is to protect people and property, or who keeps watch over prisoners. Nils got a job as a security guard. I managed to escape while my guards were asleep.
noun A guard is also a cover over something to stop people from having an accident or to stop the thing from being damaged. The guard must be kept on this machine at all times.
guard against If you guard against something, you take precautions to prevent it from happening. We took on extra staff to guard against production shortages.

noun A guardian is someone who is legally appointed to make decisions on behalf of a child or someone who is severely mentally handicapped or mentally ill. Jim's parents were killed in a car accident and his aunt is his legal guardian. If you are under 18, you must get this form signed by a parent or guardian.

guardian angel Your guardian angel is the spirit that looks after you and makes sure that nothing bad happens to you. Everyone said that Mary's guardian angel was watching over her when she survived the accident without a scratch.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun guardianship

form.definition: noun A guerilla is a member of a small armed force that fights a much larger army by making raids. The guerillas made several surprise attacks into enemy territory during the night and retreated to the hills at daybreak.

verb If you guess about something, you estimate it or choose an answer which you think may be right. You have to guess how many beans are in the jar. Red? Blue? No, I'm just guessing. Guess who I met today? If you guess wrong, you lose a turn.

noun A guess is an attempt to answer a question when you don't know much about it. My guess is we'll arrive about seven. It was just a lucky guess. I'll give you three guesses about what's for dinner. I've no ideayour guess is as good as mine.
verb In informal language, if you say you guess something is the case, you mean that you think or suppose it's so. I guess you must be tired. He'll be here soon, I guess.

noun A guest is someone you have invited to a function or to stay with you in your home. There were two hundred guests at the party. We've got guests from overseas next week. Each member can bring two guests.
noun A guest on a radio or television show is someone who does not appear on it regularly but gives a special interview or performance. My special guest this evening is H.G. Nelson.
noun If you stay at a hotel or motel, you are a guest there.
noun A guffaw is a loud, boisterous laugh.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb guffaw

form.definition: noun Guidance is help and advice from someone who is qualified to give it. Children need guidance from their parents. We are seeking guidance from our lawyers about what our options are. Some people turn to ministers of religion for guidance.
noun A guide is someone whose job is to show people around somewhere. Our guide gave us an interesting talk on the history of the area. Najib's training to be a tour guide.
noun A guide is a book which gives you information or instructions about something. This guide to Adelaide contains a list of hotels. I'm looking for a beginner's guide to home renovation.
noun A guide is an approximate indication of how to do something. Can you give me a guide about what to expect? You should allow about $200, as a guide.
verb If you guide someone somewhere, you show them the way or lead them there. She guided me towards the open door. Before satellite navigation sailors used the stars to guide them.

If you guide someone, you advise them about what to do. Can you guide me about applying for an extension to my visa? When I first arrived in Australia I was very pleased to have my brother to guide me.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See guidance.

form.definition: noun Guile is the cleverness and cunning that someone uses to deceive people. She was innocent and totally without guile.
noun Guilt is the fact of having done something wrong. It was hard for her to admit her guilt.
noun Guilt is the bad feeling you have when you've done something wrong and you're sorry about it. He was haunted by a terrible sense of guilt.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective guilty (guiltier, guiltiest) The jury found him guilty. She felt guilty about lying to her friend.

form.definition: noun A guitar is a musical instrument which looks like a large violin. It is made of wood and has six strings which you pluck with your fingers to produce sound.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun guitarist

form.definition: noun A gulf is a large stretch of sea which extends far into the surrounding land.
noun A gulf is a great difference between things. I was shocked by the gulf between the lives of the rich and the poor. A gulf developed between the brothers as a result of their argument.
noun Your gullet is the tube in your body which takes food and drink from your mouth to your stomach. He choked when he got a piece of chicken stuck in his gullet.

adjective If someone is gullible, they are very trusting and naive, and it is easy to deceive them. He was gullible enough to fall for the scheme. Mara's so gullible she'll believe anything you tell her.
noun A gully is a narrow valley in the side of a hill or mountain.
noun A gully is also a deep ditch.
verb If you gulp a liquid, you swallow it quickly in large mouthfuls. I gulped the water gratefully.
verb If you gulp air, you take very deep breaths through your mouth. He came to the surface gulping for air.
If you gulp down food or drink, you consume it very quickly. He gulped down his dinner and rushed out again.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun gulp I took a gulp from the bottle.

form.definition: noun Gum is a sticky substance that comes from some trees and shrubs including the eucalyptus.
noun Gum is also a clear water-soluble glue that is used to stick things together. There's not enough gum on the back of this envelope to stick properly.
noun Gum is also a soft, rubbery substance that people chew.
form.note: ... ANOTHER TERMfor this is chewing gum.

form.definition: verb If you gum something, you glue it. She licked the flap of the envelope and gummed it down.
gums Your gums are the firm, pink, fleshy parts around your teeth. You should floss regularly to keep your gums healthy.
noun Gumboots are loose-fitting rubber boots which come up to your knees. You wear them in heavy rain or to wade through water or mud.
noun A gun is a weapon which fires bullets or shells. Pistols, rifles and cannons are all types of guns.
jump the gun If you jump the gun, you do something before you should. The journalist jumped the gun and released the story too early.

stick to your guns If you stick to your guns, you refuse to change your mind about something, even though people try to make you. He said the car was blue and stuck to his guns when the others said it was black.
verb If water gurgles, it flows with a loud, bubbling sound. The water gurgled down the drain.
verb If someone gurgles, they make a sound in their throat which sounds like gurgling water. He gurgled with pleasure at the prospect.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun gurgle We could hear gurgles of laughter coming from the kitchen.adjective gurgling We paddled in a gurgling creek.

form.definition: verb If liquid gushes, it flows forcefully in large quantities. Water was gushing from the burst main.
verb If someone gushes, they express their enthusiasm or flatter someone in a rather exaggerated and silly way. 'Oh, Mrs Williams, you look just like a famous film star,' gushed Amanda.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun gush He poured out the story in a gush of words.adjective gushing The critics have praised the movie in gushing terms.

form.definition: noun A gust is a sudden blast of wind. A gust of wind blew his hat off.
noun If you do something with gusto, you show great enthusiasm and enjoyment in doing it. Ann described her plan with gusto. The singers performed with great gusto.
noun A person's or an animal's guts are their intestines.
noun In informal language, your gut is your abdomen. Eva hit him in the gut. He's got a really gross beer gut.
noun Gut is also a type of strong string made from the intestine of an animal. The strings on my tennis racquet are made of gut.
noun If you know or feel something in your gut, you are aware of it through your intuition, even though you don't have any clear evidence for it. My gut tells me that what you're saying is wrong.
verb If you gut a dead animal or fish, you remove its internal organs.
If a building is gutted, the inside is totally destroyed so that only the outer shell remains. The factory was gutted by fire. We practically gutted the house before we renovated.
guts (a) In informal language, if you say that someone has guts, you mean that they are very brave and determined. He had the guts to stand up to his father.
(b) The guts of a machine are its internal mechanism. The paper's got screwed up somewhere in the guts of the photocopier. He had the guts of the motorbike spread all round the garage.
(c) The guts of something are the most important parts of it. The guts of the report are summarised on the last page. He's good in meetings because he always gets straight to the guts of a problem.

hate someone's guts If you hate someone's guts, you dislike them very much indeed. Ali really hates my guts since I beat him in the exams. ... WORD FAMILYadjective gut ...a gut feeling about something.adjective gutsy (gutsier, gutsiest) He's a gutsy fighter.
noun The gutter is the edge of the roadway, where it curves down and meets the pavement. Rain rushed down the drains and into the gutters.

noun A gutter is a hollow length of plastic or metal attached along the edge of a building's roof. When it rains, the gutter collects water from the roof and drains it away. To protect your house against bushfires, keep the gutters free of fallen leaves.

noun The gutter is the lowest level of society, where conditions and standards are particularly bad. The book is about a poor boy who fought his way up out of the gutter and ended up president of his country. We don't use the language of the gutter in this house!

noun In informal language, a guy is a man. The plural of this word is also sometimes used for groups of women. Evan's a really nice guy. Who's that guy in the back row with a moustache? Pointing at the women in uniform she said, 'Just ask those guys over there'.
verb If you guzzle food or drink, you consume it very quickly and greedily. The boys guzzled up all the food in less than ten minutes. I can't believe you guzzled the whole bottle on your own!
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun guzzler Trini's a real guzzlershe can easily eat three hamburgers at a go.

form.definition: noun Gym is a short form of gymnasium.
noun Gym is a short form of gymnastics. I like gym much more than hockey or netball.
noun A gymnasium is a room or building with sporting equipment on which athletes train.
noun Gymnastics is a sport that involves performing complicated twists and somersaults on the floor and on pieces of apparatus such as the beam and bars.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun gymnast adjective gymnastic

form.definition: noun A gynaecologist is a doctor who specialises in treating medical problems that affect women only.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this is gynecologist.

form.definition: noun Gypsy is another spelling for gipsy.[fa[xp
